page.title: 06Sheep milking/Creca
page.content: Sheep have been milked since the dawn of civilisation and the milk used to produce a variety of cheeses. Traditional British pressed cheeses were all originally made with ewes milk, and gradually became cow milk cheeses as farming methods changed, and fewer people worked on the land. At Windyknowe farm one hundred ewes are milked twice daily through a specially modified milking parlour for nine to ten months of the year. Freisland sheep bred for long lactation are used, producing between four and six hundred litres per ewe per lactation. All the milk produced is turned into a hard white cheese called Barac. Freisland sheep can produce two or more lambs, a heavy quality fleece and a lean carcass as an added bonus over conventional sheep -keeping.
